messageBody:
On Sat, 20 Mar 2004, Ron Jeffries wrote:

> I think of tests, test cases, and test suites this way:
>
> TestSuite (1)--->(n)TestCase(1)--->(n)Test

Yes, I understand that now. But what advantage does having three
entities, rather than just two, give you? Well, I suppose that you
can have a bunch of test cases sharing common setup/teardown code,
but I'm not sure that you need this to be something separate than a
TestSuite, since a TestSuite uses the composite pattern anyway, and so
can aggregate instances of itself.

Just as a data point, here are Robert V. Binder's definitions of some of
these terms, from the glossary of _Testing Object-Oriented Systems_:

test. (1) An activity in which a system or a component is executed
under specified conditions, the results are observed or recorded,
and an evaluation is made of some aspect of the system or component.
... (3) A set of one or more test cases. (4) A set of one or more
test procedures. (5) A set of one or more test cases and procedures
[IEEE 610]

test case. A set of inputs, execution conditions, and expected
results developed for a particular objective. A representation or
implementation that defines a pretest state of the IUT and its
environment, test inputs or conditions, and the exepcted result.

test suite. (1) A related collection of test cases. A collection
of test case sequences that serve a particular testing goal for
a particular version of an IUT. A whole-part relationship exists
among test cases. ...

(IEEE 610 is the _ANSI/IEEE standard 610.12-1990: glossary of software
engineering terminology._)

So according to this terminology, I'd use

TestSuite (1) ---> (n) TestCase

or perhaps, if I found a good reason to

Test (1) ---> (n) TestSuite (1) ---> (n) TestCase

The current terminology actually caused me several years of confusion,
though I understand it now.

Anyway, I've gotten used to other things, such as consistently refering
to developer tests as the "unit tests," even though any major XP project
I've worked on has had quite a few developer tests that were not unit
tests and--though fewer--unit tests that were not developer tests. So
I suppose I'll eventually get used to this, too. Still, it would be
nice if this followed what appears to me to be fairly standard testing
terminology. (Sorry, I'm not an expert on testing, so I may be wrong
about this.)
